description: From Middle English aswagen, from Old French asuagier (“to appease, to calm”), from Vulgar Latin *assuāviō (“I sweeten, I butter up, I calm”), derived from Latin ad- + suāvis (“sweet”) + -iō.

verbs.description: assuage (third-person singular simple present assuages, present participle assuaging, simple past and past participle assuaged)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To lessen the intensity of, to mitigate or relieve (hunger, emotion, pain etc.).
examples: Refreshing winds the summer's heat assuage.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, obsolete) To calm down, become less violent (of passion, hunger etc.); to subside, to abate.
